etymologies: Old English hrēod, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch riet and German Ried

definitions: a tall, slender-leaved plant of the grass family, which grows in water or on marshy ground.

notes.text: Genera Phragmites and Arundo, family Gramineae: several species, in particular the Norfolk reed or common reed (P. australis), which is used for thatching

definitions: used in names of plants similar to the reed and growing in wet habitats, e.g. bur reed.
shortDefinitions: used in names of plants similar to reed

definitions: reeds growing in a mass or used as material, especially for making thatch or household items
shortDefinitions: tall straight stalk of reed plant

definitions: the tall, thin, straight stalk of a reed, used especially as material for thatching.
a rustic musical pipe made from a reed or from straw

examples.text: as if thy waves had only heard the shepherd's reed

shortDefinitions: rustic musical pipe made from reed

examples.text: the jurors were mere reeds in the wind

definitions: a piece of thin cane or metal, sometimes doubled, that vibrates in a current of air to produce the sound of various musical instruments, as in the mouthpiece of a clarinet or oboe, at the base of some organ pipes, and as part of a set in the accordion and harmonica
shortDefinitions: piece of thin cane or metal, sometimes doubled, which vibrates in current of air

definitions: a wind instrument played with a reed.
an organ stop with reed pipes.
an electrical contact used in a magnetically operated switch or relay

examples.text: the permanent magnet closes the reeds and contacts together

shortDefinitions: electrical contact used in magnetically operated switch or relay

definitions: a comblike implement (originally made from reed or cane) used by a weaver to separate the threads of the warp and correctly position the weft.
shortDefinitions: comblike implement for separating threads of warp and correctly positioning weft

definitions: a set of semicylindrical adjacent moldings like reeds laid together.
shortDefinitions: set of semi-cylindrical adjacent mouldings like reeds laid together
